anchor.surface_text: We may now read s. 13- Where any person holds land, from which agricultural income is derived, as a common manager appointed under any law for the time being in force or under any agreement or as receiver, administrator or the like on behalf of persons jointly interested in such land or in the agricultural income derived thereform, the aggregate of the sums payable as agricultural income-tax by each person on the agricultural income derived from such land and received by him shall be assessed on such common manager, receiver, administrator or the like, and he shall be deemed to be the assessee in respect of the agricultural income-tax so payable by each such person and shall be liable to pay the same.

concepts.interpretation: Court quotes and interprets: applies where common manager holds land on behalf of persons jointly interested; does not apply to partnership.

anchor.surface_text: We may not refer to some of the provisions of the Act which bear upon the question before us. S. 2 of the Act is the definition section. concepts.interpretation: Charges tax on total agricultural income of every person, including firm by definition.

anchor.surface_text: In Lindley on Partnership (Twelfth Edition page 57) the main differences between co-ownership and partnership have been compared. One of the principal differences is that co-ownership is not necessarily the result of agreement, whereas partnership is... The second difference is that co-ownership does not necessarily involve community of profit or of loss, but partnership does... A third difference is that one co owner can without the consent of the other, transfer his interest etc, to a stranger. A partner cannot do this.

concepts.interpretation: Court applies multi-factor test distinguishing co-ownership (no necessary agreement, no necessary community of profit/loss, no mutual agency, transferable interest) from partnership; facts show co-ownership, no agency between owners.

concepts.unlisted_description: Factors: agreement required for partnership not co-ownership; community of profit/loss; mutual agency; restriction on transfer of interest.

anchor.surface_text: The greatest difficulty which faces the respondent in the present cases is that it cannot point to any fact or circumstance from which it can be inferred that one proprietor was the agent, real or implied, of the other. In a partnership each partner acts for all. In a co-ownership one coowner is not as such the agent, real or implied, of the other.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence or finding of mutual agency between proprietors; essential for partnership under Indian Partnership Act s.4

holdings.text: no fact and circumstances have been found in these cases from which the taxing authorities properly instructed in law could have come to the conclusion that the assessee was a partnership firm within the meaning of s. 2(k) of the Act. On the contrary the facts and circumstances found by the taxing authorities were all consistent with the claim of the assessee that it was a co-ownership concern the common manager whereof was liable to assessment under s. 13 of the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts including joint purchase, undivided lands, common manager appointment, proportional profit sharing consistent with co-ownership not partnership; applied Lindley distinctions and Partnership Act definition

holdings.text: s. 13 will apply if the assessee is a co-ownership concern as distinguished from a partnership firm and the common manager thereof must be assessed in respect of the aggregate of the sums payable as agricultural income-tax by each such co-owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.13: applies to common manager holding on behalf of jointly interested persons (co-owners), not partnerships; noted concessions by both counsel

anchor.surface_text: Now, partnership or notpartnership is ordinarily a question of fact, but we agree with learned counsel for the assessee that it is a mixed question of fact and law in the sense that if the authorities who have to ascertain question of fact apply a wrong principle of law in instructing themselves as to what they have to find, then their finding of fact is not conclusive because they have done it according to wrong principles
We accordingly allow the anneals and set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court dated September 29, 1959, and answer the question in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The greatest difficulty which faces the respondent in the present cases is that it cannot point to any fact or circumstance from which it can be inferred that one proprietor was the agent, real or implied, of the other. In a partnership each partner acts for all. In a co-ownership one coowner is not as such the agent, real or implied, of the other.
We accordingly allow the anneals and set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court dated September 29, 1959, and answer the question in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the anneals and set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court dated September 29, 1959, and answer the question in favour of the assessee.

edges.explanation: Holding that s.13 applies if co-ownership directly addresses issue of manager assessment under s.13
The holding directly answers the issue by stating that s.13 applies to assess the common manager in a co-ownership concern (as opposed to partnership) in respect of the aggregate income.

anchor.surface_text: We may now read s. 13- Where any person holds land, from which agricultural income is derived, as a common manager appointed under any law for the time being in force or under any agreement or as receiver, administrator or the like on behalf of persons jointly interested in such land or in the agricultural income derived thereform, the aggregate of the sums payable as agricultural income-tax by each person on the agricultural income derived from such land and received by him shall be assessed on such common manager
We accordingly allow the anneals and set aside the judgment and orders of the High Court dated September 29, 1959, and answer the question in favour of the assessee.
